metadata.case_name: Standard Vacuum Refining Co. of India Ltd. v. Its Workmen
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 416 of 1958 and 19 of 1959

facts.text: Industrial dispute between Standard Vacuum Refining Co. of India Ltd. (appellant in CA 416/58) and its workmen (respondents in CA 416/58, appellants in CA 19/59) relating to claim for bonus for the year commencing January 1, 1956, and ending December 31, 1956.
Respondents claimed bonus equivalent to nine months total earnings inclusive of all allowances and overtime and extra-time earnings.
Conciliation officer attempted conciliation under s. 12(4) of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947; efforts failed, failure report submitted.
Government of Bombay referred dispute to Industrial Tribunal, Bombay under s. 12(5) of the Act in Reference I.T. No. 218 of 1957; Award dated January 13, 1958.
Respondents include 648 employees: 524 operatives and 124 clerical cadre.

Before Tribunal, respondents alleged appellant admitted capacity to pay entire bonus claim during conciliation and urged no need for Full Bench formula; claimed not paying living wage, large gap exists.

Appellant denied admitting capacity to pay entire claim; denied entitlement to bonus as paying living wage, no gap; provided calculations of average wages; voluntarily paid three months basic wages as bonus.

Tribunal found material insufficient for definite opinion on living wage; observed dispute not relating to wage scales, living wage illusive concept; held wages fair but gap exists in large number of cases; awarded five months basic earnings excluding dearness and other allowances and overtime as bonus.
Appellant agreed to apply decision to subsequent years until 1963; specific agreement for five years thereafter on wage-structure and bonus.
Average wages: operatives Rs. 273.65 np., clerks Rs. 370.11 np., total Rs. 301.16 np. (including basic, dearness allowance, amenities).

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant is paying a living wage to the respondents, rendering them not entitled to any bonus.
What is the quantum of bonus to be awarded to the respondents.

petitioner_arguments.text: Denied admitting capacity to pay entire bonus; paying living wage, no gap between actual and living wage, so no entitlement to bonus; supported by average wage calculations exceeding estimated living wage of Rs. 192.50 np.; relied on Textile Labour Committee 1940 report (Rs. 50-55 living wage then, indexed by 3.5).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Full Bench formula; decisions of this Court and tribunals

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal's finding on living wage vague; should have made definite finding; request remand for further evidence rejected by court.
Five months bonus too high; suggest ceiling on bonus to discourage excessive claims.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant admitted capacity during conciliation; no need for Full Bench formula; not paying living wage, large gap; bonus to fill gap; wages approximate need-based minimum Rs. 209.70 np. per Tripartite resolution 1957.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: 15th Indian Labour Conference resolution July 1957; Health Bulletin No. 23

respondent_arguments.text: Tribunal erred in not awarding higher than five months basic wages.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal's approach to living wage partly justified as material meagre; oil companies' plea consistently rejected; no remand as appellant knew implications.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Material insufficient; plea academic given voluntary payments and agreements.

court_reasoning.text: Living wage dynamic, idealistic concept per Art. 43; includes frugal comfort, education, insurance, etc.; not reached in underdeveloped economy; averages (Rs. 273-370) below living wage, above need-based minimum.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Textile Committee 1940 figure Rs. 50-55 was need-based minimum, not living wage; indexing defective.

court_reasoning.text: Rejected precedents relying on Textile report as erroneous; prior tribunals correctly rejected plea.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No employer yet proved living wage; bonus valid till then.

court_reasoning.text: No ceiling on bonus; depends on facts, wages, profits; five months strikes fair balance; no interference.

holdings.text: Appellant not paying living wage; gap exists; entitled to bonus.
Five months basic earnings bonus award upheld as reasonable.

outcome.summary: Both cross-appeals dismissed; Tribunal's award of five months basic earnings as bonus upheld; company's plea of paying living wage rejected; no bonus entitlement denied.

key_quotes.text: the concept of a living wage is not a static concept; it is expanding and the content of its constituents and their respective contents are bound to expand and widen with the development and growth of national economy.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines living wage as dynamic and idealistic.

key_quotes.text: in an under-developed country it would be idle to describe any wage structure as containing the ideal of the living wage.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: awarding five months bonus strikes a fair balance between the conflicting standards of the workmen and the company.
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
